ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Recurrence of left CPA meningioma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Strongly indicated by asymmetric SNHL, significant rollover (RI 0.71), and absent acoustic reflexes in the left ear.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Cisplatin ototoxicity
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Consistent with the bilateral high-frequency nature of the hearing loss and concurrent chemotherapy.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Noise-induced hearing loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Supported by the bilateral notch at 6000 Hz and history of occupational noise exposure.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Standard assessment to determine degree, configuration, and symmetry of hearing loss.
To assess speech recognition and evaluate for rollover, which differentiates cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
To evaluate middle ear status and rule out conductive pathology.
To test the reflex arc; absence or elevation can indicate retrocochlear pathology.
To confirm tumor status and evaluate potential recurrence or progression of the left CPA meningioma.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Current evaluation reveals bilateral asymmetric SNHL. While high-frequency loss is consistent with cisplatin ototoxicity, the left ear exhibits distinct retrocochlear signs (rollover, absent reflexes) suggesting tumor recurrence.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right slight SNHL (250-2k Hz) sloping to moderate/mod-severe (3k-8k Hz). Left mild SNHL (500-1500 Hz) decreasing to mod-severe (2k-3k Hz), significantly poorer than right.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right WRS 98%. Left WRS 68% decreasing to 20% at higher levels (Rollover Index 0.71).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Right ipsilateral normal. Left ipsilateral elevated at 500 Hz, absent at 1k/2k Hz. Left contralateral absent.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Historical examination from 3 years prior revealed a sudden left-sided sensorineural hearing loss with disproportionately poor speech recognition, leading to the initial diagnosis of a left CPA meningioma.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear normal to slight loss. Left ear moderate-severe SNHL at 1.5-6 kHz with very poor WRS (8%).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Historical examination from 1 year prior (post-Gamma Knife) showed recovery of hearing thresholds to near-normal levels, with a persistent noise notch.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Thresholds returned to normal/near-normal with a bilateral notch at 6000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: WRS 100% bilaterally with normal speech recognition.

proposed_items: Replace cisplatin with a less ototoxic chemotherapeutic agent
Continue consistent use of hearing protection
counseling_actions: Discuss the discrepancy between expected ototoxicity patterns and the observed retrocochlear signs in the left ear
Explain the significance of rollover and absent reflexes as indicators of potential tumor recurrence
Emphasize the critical need for an MRI to check meningioma status
Counsel on preventing further noise-induced damage

red_flags_present: Significant rollover (RI 0.71) in the left ear
Absent acoustic reflexes with mild/moderate hearing loss

escalation.rationale_short: Critical need for MRI to evaluate potential recurrence or progression of the left CPA meningioma given retrocochlear findings.

follow_up_plan.objective: Obtain MRI to confirm tumor status and adjust medical management accordingly.

expected_outcome: MRI scan following the audiological examination indicated progression of the left meningioma (2.7 x 2.9 x 2.4 cm) with compression of the left brachium pontis and anterior encroachment of the left IAC.
Cisplatin was replaced with a less ototoxic chemotherapeutic agent due to documentation of hearing loss.
Treatment for the meningioma was postponed due to the aggressive nature of the mesothelioma.
The patient passed away 7 months later.
